title: Huntington's Disease
icd10: F02.80 (Dementia in HD without behavioral disturbance)
F02.81 (Dementia in HD with behavioral disturbance)
scope: ** Diagnosis confirmation via genetic testing, chorea management, psychiatric symptom treatment, cognitive decline management, dysphagia assessment, genetic counseling, and end-of-life planning. Focuses primarily on outpatient management. Excludes Huntington disease-like syndromes (HDL1-4) and other chorea etiologies.

Essential/Core Labs.target: â‰¥36 CAG repeats diagnostic (40+ fully penetrant)

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; anemia contributes to fatigue; infection screen
Electrolytes; renal function for medication dosing
Baseline before tetrabenazine/deutetrabenazine; valproate if used
Hypothyroidism can mimic apathy and cognitive slowing
Deficiency can worsen cognitive and psychiatric symptoms
Deficiency common; contributes to falls and bone health

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Neurodegeneration with brain iron accumulation if HD-negative
Wilson's disease if younger onset, HD gene-negative
Research; may modify age of onset
Nutritional status assessment in advanced disease

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.item: Genetic testing for HDL syndromes (PRNP, JPH3, TBP, ATN1) (CPT 81479)
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: HD-like phenotype with negative HTT test

Essential/First-line.target: Caudate atrophy; lateral ventricle enlargement ("boxcar" ventricles)

Extended.target: Quantify caudate and striatal volume loss

Extended.timing: At diagnosis and with dysphagia symptoms
Extended.target: Identify aspiration risk; guide diet modification
Rule out sleep apnea; assess sleep architecture

Rare/Specialized.target: Identifies modifiers of age of onset

Acute/Emergent.indication: Severe chorea causing injury or exhaustion

dosing.instructions: 0.5-2 mg IV/PO q4-6h PRN; short-term use only

Acute/Emergent.indication: Severe psychosis with agitation; acute behavioral emergency

dosing.instructions: 2-5 mg IM; may repeat q4-6h; max 20 mg/day; transition to oral

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: QTc prolongation; history of NMS; worsens dystonia

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute agitation with psychosis; alternative to haloperidol

dosing.instructions: 5-10 mg IM; may repeat in 2 hours; max 30 mg/day

Acute/Emergent.indication: Dehydration from dysphagia or decreased oral intake

doseOptions.orderSentence: IV fluids NS at 75 mL/hr IV

dosing.instructions: NS at 75-125 mL/hr; correct dehydration; transition to oral when safe
dosing.orderSentence: IV fluids NS at 75 mL/hr IV

dosing.instructions: 100 mg IV daily x 3-5 days; then oral
Start 12.5 mg daily; increase by 12.5 mg q1wk; max 100 mg/day (25 mg per dose); CYP2D6 testing recommended

Symptomatic Treatments - Chorea.contraindications: Active suicidality; untreated depression; concurrent MAOIs; hepatic impairment

Symptomatic Treatments - Chorea.indication: FDA-approved for HD chorea; better tolerability than tetrabenazine

dosing.instructions: Start 6 mg daily; increase by 6 mg/wk; max 48 mg/day (24 mg per dose)

Symptomatic Treatments - Chorea.contraindications: Active suicidality; untreated depression; concurrent MAOIs; hepatic impairment

Symptomatic Treatments - Chorea.indication: Off-label for HD chorea; once daily dosing

dosing.instructions: Start 40 mg daily; may increase to 80 mg after 1 week

Symptomatic Treatments - Chorea.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent MAOIs; congenital long QT

Symptomatic Treatments - Chorea.indication: Chorea with psychosis; antipsychotic with motor benefit

dosing.instructions: Start 0.5 mg daily; titrate by 0.5 mg q1wk; max 6 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Chorea.indication: Chorea with weight loss; promotes weight gain

dosing.instructions: Start 2.5-5 mg qHS; titrate to effect; typical 5-15 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Chorea.indication: Adjunct for chorea; also helps myoclonus and anxiety

dosing.instructions: Start 0.25 mg BID; titrate slowly; max 4 mg/day
Start 100 mg daily; titrate to 100 mg TID; max 400 mg/day
Start 25 mg daily; titrate by 25-50 mg q1-2wk; max 200 mg/day
Start 10 mg daily; max 20 mg/day due to QTc risk
Start 5-10 mg daily; max 20 mg/day
Start 37.5 mg daily; titrate q1wk; max 225 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Psychiatric.indication: Depression with insomnia and weight loss; promotes appetite

dosing.instructions: Start 7.5-15 mg qHS; titrate q1-2wk; max 45 mg

Symptomatic Treatments - Psychiatric.indication: Psychosis; irritability; insomnia; less EPS than other antipsychotics

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg qHS; titrate by 25-50 mg q3d; typical 150-400 mg/day
Start 2-5 mg daily; titrate by 5 mg q1wk; max 30 mg/day
Start 25 mg daily x 2wk; then 50 mg daily x 2wk; titrate by 50 mg q2wk; max 400 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Psychiatric.contraindications: History of severe rash with lamotrigine

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg BID; titrate to level 50-100 mcg/mL
Start 100 mg BID; titrate by 200 mg/wk; target level 4-12 mcg/mL

Symptomatic Treatments - Psychiatric.contraindications: AV block; blood dyscrasias; concurrent MAOIs
Symptomatic Treatments - Psychiatric.monitoring: CBC, LFTs, level, HLA-B*1502 in Asians

Symptomatic Treatments - Psychiatric.indication: Anxiety without sedation; adjunct for irritability

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg TID; titrate by 5 mg q2-3d; max 60 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments - Cognitive and O.indication: Cognitive impairment; limited evidence in HD

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg qHS; may increase to 10 mg after 4-6 weeks
Start 1.5 mg BID or 4.6 mg patch; titrate monthly
Start 5 mg daily; titrate by 5 mg/wk; target 10 mg BID
Start 100 mg each morning; may increase to 200 mg; avoid afternoon dosing
Start 5 mg at breakfast and lunch; titrate by 5-10 mg q1wk; max 60 mg/day
Start 25-50 mg qHS; titrate by 25-50 mg; max 200 mg for sleep
Start 3 mg 30 min before bed; may increase to 9 mg

doseOptions.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin (onabotulinumtoxinA) Variable per muscle IM

dosing.instructions: Dose depends on target muscles; repeat q12 weeks
dosing.orderSentence: Botulinum toxin (onabotulinumtoxinA) Variable per muscle IM

dosing.instructions: Start 1 mg BID; titrate to effect; max 2 mg TID

Symptomatic Treatments - Cognitive and O.indication: Constipation (common with reduced mobility and anticholinergics)

dosing.instructions: 17 g in 8 oz liquid daily; may increase to BID
1-3 cans (Ensure Plus, Boost Plus) daily between meals

Referrals & Consults.item: Huntington Disease Society of America (HDSA) Center of Excellence for comprehensive multidisciplinary care
Genetic counselor for pre-test counseling, results disclosure, and family testing discussion
Psychiatry for depression, suicidality assessment, irritability, and psychosis management
Neuropsychology for baseline and serial cognitive assessment to guide care planning
Speech-language pathology for swallowing evaluation and communication strategies
Physical therapy for gait training, fall prevention, and adaptive exercise program
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, home safety evaluation, and energy conservation
Dietitian/nutritionist for weight maintenance strategies and caloric supplementation
Social work for caregiver support, disability planning, and community resources
Palliative care for symptom management, advance care planning, and goals of care discussions
Pulmonology for respiratory assessment in advanced disease and ventilation decisions
Gastroenterology for PEG tube placement consideration in advanced dysphagia

Patient Instructions.item: CRITICAL: Report suicidal thoughts immediately as depression is common and treatable in HD
Do not drive if experiencing significant chorea, cognitive impairment, or sedating medication effects
Maintain high caloric intake (3000-4000 kcal/day may be needed) due to hypermetabolic state
Eat slowly, take small bites, and remain upright 30 minutes after meals to reduce aspiration risk
Complete advance directive and healthcare power of attorney while capacity is preserved
Inform all healthcare providers about HD as many common medications can worsen symptoms
First-degree relatives have 50% risk; genetic counseling available but genetic testing is a personal choice
Avoid alcohol which worsens balance, cognition, and interacts with medications

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (walking, swimming, stationary bike) improves motor function and mood
Fall prevention: remove home hazards, adequate lighting, grab bars, non-slip surfaces
Maintain social engagement and meaningful activities to reduce depression and apathy
Cognitive engagement through puzzles, reading, and structured activities may help maintain function
Structure daily routine with consistent timing for medications, meals, and activities
Caregiver respite and support groups essential to prevent caregiver burnout
Smoking cessation to reduce aspiration pneumonia risk and cardiovascular disease
Limit caffeine if insomnia or anxiety are problematic

differential.features: Prion protein gene mutation; similar phenotype

differential.tests: Kell antigen typing; XK gene testing

differential.features: Younger onset; Kayser-Fleischer rings; hepatic disease

evidence.recommendation: Deutetrabenazine reduces chorea with improved tolerability
CAG repeat length inversely correlates with age of onset
AAN practice parameter for HD treatment
High suicide rate in HD requires screening
evidence.source: [Paulsen et al. J Neuropsychiatry Clin Neurosci 2005](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16387989/)

evidence.recommendation: UHDRS reliable for tracking disease progression
Genetic counseling improves outcomes in at-risk individuals
Dysphagia common and associated with aspiration risk
Exercise benefits motor and cognitive function
evidence.source: [Quinn et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2022](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35994403/)

monitoring.frequency: Every visit; monthly if on VMAT2 inhibitor
monitoring.action: Intensify antidepressant; psychiatry referral if PHQ-9 >15
Modify diet texture; speech therapy; PEG consideration
Hold medication if QTc >500 ms; reduce dose
Adjust level of care; advance care planning
PT referral; home safety; medication review

disposition.criteria: Stable psychiatric status; adequate oral intake; safe swallowing; caregiver available; outpatient follow-up arranged
Severe psychiatric symptoms requiring stabilization; aspiration pneumonia; significant weight loss requiring evaluation; severe chorea causing exhaustion or injury
Aspiration with respiratory failure; severe rhabdomyolysis from chorea; neuroleptic malignant syndrome; suicidal attempt requiring medical stabilization
Advanced disease; 24-hour care needs; dysphagia requiring supervision; frequent falls; caregiver unable to provide required care
End-stage disease (TFC stage 5); recurrent aspiration; patient/family goals favor comfort care
